attributes.title: Hindsight bias in a first or second language

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Hindsight Bias: Is it stronger when using a native or foreign language?

sample.value: We will recruit 400 participants, with 200 per language condition.

analyses.value: We will run an independent t-test examining differences in the size of the hindsight bias (Expected – Actual Accuracy) across language treatments.

outliers.value: Subjects must be native Hebrew speakers that speak English as a second language, and cannot have grown up speaking English at home. Subjects will be screened for language background before entering the survey, but will be excluded if they either report a different language background in the demographics or report that they are more proficient in their foreign language (English) than their native language (Hebrew).

dependent.value:
Subjects will answer two blocks of 18 multiple choice trivia questions of comparable difficulty, with each block consisting of a different set of 18 trivia problems. In Block 1, subjects will see the correct answer highlighted in green, and then will be asked to estimate the chance they would have known the correct answer if it was not highlighted in green from 25% (completely guessing) to 100% (completely certain). In Block 2, subjects will provide their best guesses to each of the trivia problems. Assignment of trivia lists to block will be counterbalanced across participants, so that some participants get the first list of trivia problems as Block 1 and others get the first list of trivia problems as Block 2.  

The main DV of interest will be the difference between estimated accuracy (in Block 1) minus actual accuracy (in Block 2) across language conditions.

conditions.value: Participants will either be assigned to complete the study in their native language Hebrew or foreign language English (Language: Native | Foreign, between subjects).

hypothesis.value:
We are aiming to examine how reading information in a native versus foreign language influences susceptibility to hindsight bias. Hindsight bias is the propensity for subjects to “correct” their memory for their original response in the direction of the correct answer (Fischhoff, 1977), thereby overestimating how likely they would have correctly responded if they were not provided with the correct answer. 

Our research question is: (1) Are individuals more susceptible to hindsight bias when using their native or foreign language?

q1.value: Time Horizon, Control and Financial Wellbeing

q3.value:
Previous Morningstar Inc. research using participants from MTurk showed a significant, positive correlation between long mental time horizon (as measured by how far into the future they tend to think and plan, and how clear and detailed that picture is) and better financial health (as measured by greater savings relative to income, and overall self-reported stress measures). In addition, we found that people who believed they control their own financial future were significantly less financially stressed and saved significantly more than those who reported believing they do not control their financial destiny.

This study aims to determine if the same findings are replicated in a nationally representative sample.

q4.value:
Morningstar Mental Factors and Financial Wellbeing

HYPOTHESES


From our measures, we produce the composite variable Savings / Income (S/I):

S/I=  (Total savings & investment balance)/(Annual income)

Our data set for analysis is as follows:
Variables
Dependent	Explanatory
Name	Notation	Name	Notation
Financial stress frequency	Stress	Age	A
Savings / Income	S / I	Income	I
		Education	E
		Gender	G – dummy variable
		Mental time horizon	T
		Construal level of the future	CL
		Perceived control over financial future	LOC

		Savings balance	S



Hypothesis A:
Ha(0): There is no significant difference between the savings/income ratio of people who think 10+ years into the future and those who thing fewer than ten years into the future.

Ha(1): Those who think 10 or more years into the future will have a significantly higher savings/income ratio than those who have a shorter mental time horizon.
- This relationship will remain significant when controlling for the following:
age
income
education
gender

	
Hypothesis B
Hb(0): There is no significant difference in the savings/income ratio of those who have detailed mental imagery vs. those who have vague mental imagery.
Hb(1): Those who have a clearer mental image of the future will have significantly greater savings/income ratio than those who have vague and unformed mental imagery of their future.
- This relationship will remain significant when controlling for the following:
age
income
education
gender

	
Hypothesis C
Hc(0): There is no significant difference between the stress levels of those who feel in control of their financial future vs. those who do not.
Hc(1): Those who believe they control their financial future will report significantly lower stress than those who do not.


Hypothesis D
Hd(0): The interaction between mental time horizon and construal level of the future (as measured by clarity of mental imagery) is not significantly related to the savings/income ratio.
Hd(1): The interaction of mental imagery and time horizon has a significant, positive relationship with savings/income.
- This relationship will remain significant when controlling for the following:
age
income
education
gender



The same Hypotheses will be tested with Financial Stress as the dependent variable. All of the same relationships are expected.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study involves a simple survey including measures of financial stability (savings/income), financial stress (self-reported stress level), mental time time horizon, and feelings of control. Demographic information will also be collected for the purpose of controls.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A large, nationally representative sample (survey distributed through NORC) will complete the questionnaire as a part of a larger survey on the financial lives of Americans.

q13.value: We are planning on a sample of between 800 and 1,000 US adults.

q14.value: Previous work using MTurk respondents found significant correlations between our independent and dependent variables with N= 270 and N= 700. We are confident that a sample size of 800 will detect any meaningful correlations if they exist.

q15.value: N/A if we do not see a significant correlation with 800 people, we conclude the relationship is not meaningful.

question.value: No manipulation
The Measures.doc document has the precise wording of the questions we will be asking as well as the list of demographic variables collected.
We will test our hypotheses using the following statistical analyses, explained in the attached document

attributes.title: Shared and Differential Neurocognitive Mechanisms in Obesity and Binge Eating Disorder from Adolescence to Adulthood: An Attempt to Improve Prediction of Clinical Outcome
attributes.description: This preregistration gives an overview of the background, overarching hypotheses, and design of a large study consisting of several subprojects. Detailed information about the subprojects and the respective analysis plans can be found in separate preregistrations.

summary.value:
SHARED AND DIFFERENTIAL NEUROCOGNITIVE MECHANISMS IN OBESITY AND BINGE EATING DISORDER FROM ADOLESCENCE TO ADULTHOOD: AN ATTEMPT TO IMPROVE PREDICTION OF CLINICAL OUTCOME


This preregistration gives an overview of the background, overarching hypotheses, and design of a large study consisting of several subprojects. Detailed information about the subprojects and the respective analysis plans can be found in separate preregistrations. 

At the time of submission, data acquisition has started. 130 full datasets have been collected so far. The data have not been analyzed before preregistration and were only accessed for sanity checks that did not address any of the research questions.

1. SUMMARY
Previous research into the neurocognitive profiles of obesity and binge eating disorder (BED) has revealed difficulties with working memory and adaptive decision-making in both conditions [e.g. 1–6]. However, the overlapping and differential aspects of these neurocognitive profiles have not been systematically studied so far. For example, it is unclear whether obese individuals with and without BED have distinctive alterations regarding the maintenance and updating aspects of working memory. Similarly, although there is some indication that both BED patients’ and obese individuals’ decision making is differentially affected depending on a task’s motivational context (obtain rewards vs to avoid punishments) [1,7], this has not consistently been taken into account. Further, it is unclear at what point during development putative differences emerge, whether neurocognitive profiles change as symptom expression changes, and whether initial differences could be predictive of future clinical outcomes. To address these gaps in the literature, we study a cohort of obese adolescents and adults with and without BED in comparison with age- and gender-matched normal-weight controls. We investigate several facets of decision-making in different motivational contexts as well as working memory with and without functional MRI, at two time points spaced by approximately 6 months. Moreover, we assess neuropsychological measures, self reported eating behaviour, mood, and personality. Finally, because alterations in dopaminergic signalling have previously been implicated in all cognitive constructs studied [8–10] as well as BED [11] and obesity e.g. [12], we further probe whether interindividual and intergroup differences in our neurocognitive measures are associated with genetic and physiological proxies of prefrontal and striatal dopamine turnover.

2. GENERAL HYPOTHESES
I. Healthy weight and obese individuals with and without binge eating disorder will differ in their neurocognitive characteristics
II. Decision-making differences will be more pronounced in situations where participants have to avoid losses
III. Differences begin to emerge in adolescence but become more pronounced with increasing chronicity of obesity and BED in adulthood
IV. Neurocognitive profiles change as symptom expression changes over time
V. Interindividual and intergroup differences will be associated with differences in proxies of dopamine transmission 

3. METHODS
3.1. PARTICIPANTS
We aim to acquire data from 240 participants, 40 participants per group.
- 40 participants (BMI: 18.5-25; healthy; age 21-50)
- 40 participants (BMI: 18.5-25; healthy; age 12-18)
- 40 participants (BMI: 30-45; obese; age 21-50)
- 40 participants (BMI above the 95th age and gender specific percentile; obese; age 12-18)
- 40 participants (BMI: 30-45; obese and BED; age 21-50)
- 40 participants (BMI above the 95th age and gender specific percentile; obese and BED; age 12-18)

Inclusion criteria:
- Written informed consent prior to participation
- Physical examination without unexpected pathological findings
- BMI between 18.5 and 45 kg/m2
- Age between 12 and 50 years

Exclusion criteria:
- BED patients: any current diagnosis or history of psychiatric disease other than BED except anxiety disorders, major depressive or dysthymic disorder, social conduct disorder, childhood disorders (e.g. enuresis), tics
- Obese individuals and lean individuals: History of psychiatric disease
- History of neurologic disease
- History of significant head injury (i.e. with loss of consciousness for longer than 30 mins)
- Pregnancy/current breast feeding
- Diabetes mellitus type I or II
- Thyroid dysfunction
- Regular intake of psychotropic medications (except antidepressants in BED patients)
- Regular drug use
- Excessive alcohol use (on average no more than 20g alcohol (1-2 beer 0,5 l)/ day)
- Contraindications to MR imaging

3.2. NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS
- Reitan Trailmaking Test A und B [13]
- Digit Span backwards [14]
- Digit Symbol Substitution Test [14]    
- WST Wortschatztest [15]

3.3. QUESTIONNAIRES
3.3.1.Eating behaviour
- Dietary Fat and Sugar Questionnaire (DFSQ) [16]
- Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (EDE-Q) [17]
- Three Factor Eating Questionnaire (TFEQ) [18,19]
- Yale Food Addiction Scale (YFAS) [20,21]
3.3.2. Clinical tests
- Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) [22,23]
- State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) [24,25]
3.3.3. Individual differences
- NEO five factor inventory (NEO-FFI) [26,27]
- Behavioural approach and avoidance system questionnaire (BIS/BAS) [28,29]
- Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (BIS 11) [30,31]
- Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance, Sensation Seeking (UPPS) Impulsive Behaviour Scale [32,33]
- Modified Weight Bias Internalization Scale (WBIS) [34]
- Rejection Sensitivity Scale (RSQ) [35]
3.3.4. Underage participants
- Depressions-Inventar für Kinder und Jugendliche (DIKJ)  [36]
- Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire Self Report (SDQs) [37,38]
- Pubertal Development Scale (PDS) [39,40]
3.3.5. Parents of underage participants
- Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ) [41,42]

3.4. INTERVIEWS
- SKID I [43]
- EDE-I [44]

3.5. NEUROCOGNITIVE TASKS
3.5.1. During fMRI: 
- Probabilistic reversal learning task in a variant that distinguishes learning from rewards and learning from punishments [45] 
- Task that tests stability vs. flexibility of working memory representations [46,47] 
3.5.2. Behaviourally: 
- Motivational biases task, a task designed to disentangle the impact of reward and punishment on instrumental learning from Pavlovian response biasing [48] 
- The Horizon Task, a task that specifically separates directed exploration of less known options from random exploration of all options [49]
- A multistep decision task in which model-based and model-free influences on human choice behaviour can be distinguished and their relative contribution to  
  actions quantified [50]

3.6. MRI
- Task based functional MRI (during reversal learning and working memory tasks) at 3T
- Structural MRI at 3T

3.7. PHYSIOLOGICAL MEASURES
3.7.1. Blood testing for Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (as genetic markers of dopamine transmission) 
- Catechol-O-Methyltransferase (rs4680)
- DRD2/ANKK1 Taq1A (rs1800497) 
- DRD2 (rs6277)
- alpha-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenase FTO (rs8053740 and rs8050136) 
- dopamine- and cAMP-regulated neuronal phosphoprotein DARPP-32 (rs907094)

3.7.2. Eye-blink rate will be measured for a duration of 5 minutes as a putative proxy for dopamine tone in the central nervous system [51](﻿but see also 52,53)

registration_responses.summary:
SHARED AND DIFFERENTIAL NEUROCOGNITIVE MECHANISMS IN OBESITY AND BINGE EATING DISORDER FROM ADOLESCENCE TO ADULTHOOD: AN ATTEMPT TO IMPROVE PREDICTION OF CLINICAL OUTCOME


This preregistration gives an overview of the background, overarching hypotheses, and design of a large study consisting of several subprojects. Detailed information about the subprojects and the respective analysis plans can be found in separate preregistrations. 

At the time of submission, data acquisition has started. 130 full datasets have been collected so far. The data have not been analyzed before preregistration and were only accessed for sanity checks that did not address any of the research questions.

1. SUMMARY
Previous research into the neurocognitive profiles of obesity and binge eating disorder (BED) has revealed difficulties with working memory and adaptive decision-making in both conditions [e.g. 1–6]. However, the overlapping and differential aspects of these neurocognitive profiles have not been systematically studied so far. For example, it is unclear whether obese individuals with and without BED have distinctive alterations regarding the maintenance and updating aspects of working memory. Similarly, although there is some indication that both BED patients’ and obese individuals’ decision making is differentially affected depending on a task’s motivational context (obtain rewards vs to avoid punishments) [1,7], this has not consistently been taken into account. Further, it is unclear at what point during development putative differences emerge, whether neurocognitive profiles change as symptom expression changes, and whether initial differences could be predictive of future clinical outcomes. To address these gaps in the literature, we study a cohort of obese adolescents and adults with and without BED in comparison with age- and gender-matched normal-weight controls. We investigate several facets of decision-making in different motivational contexts as well as working memory with and without functional MRI, at two time points spaced by approximately 6 months. Moreover, we assess neuropsychological measures, self reported eating behaviour, mood, and personality. Finally, because alterations in dopaminergic signalling have previously been implicated in all cognitive constructs studied [8–10] as well as BED [11] and obesity e.g. [12], we further probe whether interindividual and intergroup differences in our neurocognitive measures are associated with genetic and physiological proxies of prefrontal and striatal dopamine turnover.

2. GENERAL HYPOTHESES
I. Healthy weight and obese individuals with and without binge eating disorder will differ in their neurocognitive characteristics
II. Decision-making differences will be more pronounced in situations where participants have to avoid losses
III. Differences begin to emerge in adolescence but become more pronounced with increasing chronicity of obesity and BED in adulthood
IV. Neurocognitive profiles change as symptom expression changes over time
V. Interindividual and intergroup differences will be associated with differences in proxies of dopamine transmission 

3. METHODS
3.1. PARTICIPANTS
We aim to acquire data from 240 participants, 40 participants per group.
- 40 participants (BMI: 18.5-25; healthy; age 21-50)
- 40 participants (BMI: 18.5-25; healthy; age 12-18)
- 40 participants (BMI: 30-45; obese; age 21-50)
- 40 participants (BMI above the 95th age and gender specific percentile; obese; age 12-18)
- 40 participants (BMI: 30-45; obese and BED; age 21-50)
- 40 participants (BMI above the 95th age and gender specific percentile; obese and BED; age 12-18)

Inclusion criteria:
- Written informed consent prior to participation
- Physical examination without unexpected pathological findings
- BMI between 18.5 and 45 kg/m2
- Age between 12 and 50 years

Exclusion criteria:
- BED patients: any current diagnosis or history of psychiatric disease other than BED except anxiety disorders, major depressive or dysthymic disorder, social conduct disorder, childhood disorders (e.g. enuresis), tics
- Obese individuals and lean individuals: History of psychiatric disease
- History of neurologic disease
- History of significant head injury (i.e. with loss of consciousness for longer than 30 mins)
- Pregnancy/current breast feeding
- Diabetes mellitus type I or II
- Thyroid dysfunction
- Regular intake of psychotropic medications (except antidepressants in BED patients)
- Regular drug use
- Excessive alcohol use (on average no more than 20g alcohol (1-2 beer 0,5 l)/ day)
- Contraindications to MR imaging

3.2. NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS
- Reitan Trailmaking Test A und B [13]
- Digit Span backwards [14]
- Digit Symbol Substitution Test [14]    
- WST Wortschatztest [15]

3.3. QUESTIONNAIRES
3.3.1.Eating behaviour
- Dietary Fat and Sugar Questionnaire (DFSQ) [16]
- Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (EDE-Q) [17]
- Three Factor Eating Questionnaire (TFEQ) [18,19]
- Yale Food Addiction Scale (YFAS) [20,21]
3.3.2. Clinical tests
- Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) [22,23]
- State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) [24,25]
3.3.3. Individual differences
- NEO five factor inventory (NEO-FFI) [26,27]
- Behavioural approach and avoidance system questionnaire (BIS/BAS) [28,29]
- Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (BIS 11) [30,31]
- Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance, Sensation Seeking (UPPS) Impulsive Behaviour Scale [32,33]
- Modified Weight Bias Internalization Scale (WBIS) [34]
- Rejection Sensitivity Scale (RSQ) [35]
3.3.4. Underage participants
- Depressions-Inventar für Kinder und Jugendliche (DIKJ)  [36]
- Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire Self Report (SDQs) [37,38]
- Pubertal Development Scale (PDS) [39,40]
3.3.5. Parents of underage participants
- Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ) [41,42]

3.4. INTERVIEWS
- SKID I [43]
- EDE-I [44]

3.5. NEUROCOGNITIVE TASKS
3.5.1. During fMRI: 
- Probabilistic reversal learning task in a variant that distinguishes learning from rewards and learning from punishments [45] 
- Task that tests stability vs. flexibility of working memory representations [46,47] 
3.5.2. Behaviourally: 
- Motivational biases task, a task designed to disentangle the impact of reward and punishment on instrumental learning from Pavlovian response biasing [48] 
- The Horizon Task, a task that specifically separates directed exploration of less known options from random exploration of all options [49]
- A multistep decision task in which model-based and model-free influences on human choice behaviour can be distinguished and their relative contribution to  
  actions quantified [50]

3.6. MRI
- Task based functional MRI (during reversal learning and working memory tasks) at 3T
- Structural MRI at 3T

3.7. PHYSIOLOGICAL MEASURES
3.7.1. Blood testing for Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (as genetic markers of dopamine transmission) 
- Catechol-O-Methyltransferase (rs4680)
- DRD2/ANKK1 Taq1A (rs1800497) 
- DRD2 (rs6277)
- alpha-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenase FTO (rs8053740 and rs8050136) 
- dopamine- and cAMP-regulated neuronal phosphoprotein DARPP-32 (rs907094)

3.7.2. Eye-blink rate will be measured for a duration of 5 minutes as a putative proxy for dopamine tone in the central nervous system [51](﻿but see also 52,53)

attributes.title: Identity, aspirations and eating behaviours
attributes.description: This study seeks to empirically establish the involvement, position and direction of each of the three variables; identity, aspirations and behaviours, within the eating behaviours process. Using a reciprocal-effects-model, which tests the direction of the relationship between each pair of variables, this study tests the associations between identity, aspirations and eating behaviours and the location of identity in relation to aspirations and behaviours

q1.value: Identity, aspirations and eating behaviours: An exploration of the strength and direction among relationships

q3.value: Behaviour change approaches have been implemented to address eating behaviours which are partly responsible for the poor dietary habits contributing to global disease (Kelly & Barker 2016). Identities are suggested to direct and influence behaviour and when manipulated are evidenced to result in the maintenance of improved dietary behaviours (Brouwer & Mosack, 2015). The reverse may also occur, whereby behaviours shape one’s identities (Lewis & Oyserman, 2016). The link between identity and behaviour may not be direct, but through an individual’s aspirations, with identities helping to shape aspirations which then energize behaviour. Sustained behaviour change is associated with aspirations (Niemiec, Ryan & Deci, 2009). That said, reciprocal effects may also exist in which aspirations are influenced by and shape identities and behaviours. In order to offer clarification to the current research and improve interventions, it is necessary to empirically establish the involvement, position and direction of each of the three variables; identity, aspirations and behaviours, within the eating behaviour context. Please see attached Brief proposal document for further information

q4.value: Hypotheses will be tested using structural equation modelling. Please see hypothesized model attached in the Measured Variables section

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A cross-lagged longitudinal design over two time points will be employed. Participants will complete validated surveys for all variables at both time points

data.name: Brief proposal - Identity and Aspirations in Eating Behaviours.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Brief proposal - Identity and Aspirations in Eating Behaviours.docx

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants data will be sought from a convenience sample of a minimum of 246 volunteer participants. The only exclusion to participation is being below the age of 18 years of age. 

The participants will be recruited via the social media platforms of the University research participation forums, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. The researchers will also recruit participants via email adverts and word of mouth. 

The participants will be incentivised to carry out the questionnaire on two occasions through being entered into a draw following the completion of the second time questionnaire. The successful participant will win a £25 Amazon gift voucher.

q13.value:
Time 1 will collect data from a minimum of 295 participants. 
Time 2 will collect data from a minimum of 246 participants (allowing for 20% attrition)
A four week period between time points will be included.

q14.value:
No relevant or comparable studies were available and therefore, power analysis has been used to calculate a minimum and recommended sample size of 246 to detect an effect. The minimum for the model structure is 100 participants.   
Sample size calculated at https://www.danielsoper.com/statcalc/calculator.aspx?id=89. The following data was entered into the sample calculator:
an anticipated effect size of 0.25
a desired statistical power level of 0.8
the number of latent variables as 6
the number of observed variables as 24
a probability level of 0.05

question.value:
The attached "hypothesized model" document visually depicts the variables to be measured as part of the study questionnaire as follows
1. Identity - This consists of personal, relational, social and collective identity orientation sub scales (Cheek & Briggs, 2013).
2. Aspirations - This consists of image, personal growth, health and relationship sub scales (Kasser & Ryan, 1996).
3. Eating behaviours - This consists of the food approach sub scale which includes hunger and food responsiveness, emotional over eating and enjoyment of food and the food avoidance sub scale which includes slowness in eating and  emotional under eating and food fussiness, slowness in eating and satiety responsiveness (Hunot et al, 2016) 

Additional outcomes will also be collected which include
a) Weight
b) Height
c) Age

Means of the items for each subscale will be used as indicators for an overall latent factor depicting identity and aspirations, respectively. Subscales will be parcelled into four indicators for an overall eating behaviour section. Please see attached "hypothesized model" in Measured Variables section for specific details

Structural equation modelling will be the used as the method of statistical analysis in this study. Maximum likelihood estimation with robust standard errors (i.e., MLR estimator in Mplus) will be employed. Prior to testing of our hypothesized model, measurement invariance across time points will be tested in line with previous work (Marsh, Nagengast, & Morin, 2013; Marsh et al., 2010).

q21.value: Overall model fit will be assessed using RMSEA < 0.08, CFI > 0.90, SRMR < 0.08. Individual parameters will be assessed using traditional p < .05

q23.value: The default method in Mplus will be used to handle missing data (i.e., FIML)

q24.value:
We will explore any differences in the relationships observed as a function of age, gender and BMI
Also, we will explore the relationships between the subdimensions of the overall constructs (rather than overall latent factors in the hypothesized model)

attributes.title: Effects of expressive intensity and competence on persuasion
attributes.description: The project aims to examine whether the effect, the expressive intensity used by a speaker to state his opinion has on subjects’ attitude change, evaluations of trustworthiness of the speaker and credibility of the message, varies depending on perceived source competency.

q1.value: Effects of expressive intensity and competence on persuasion

q3.value:
This project is not meant to be published as an article in any journal since it serves as my bachelor thesis at the Julius-Maximilians-Universität Würzburg. Data collection started at 12th of December and finished at the 18th of December 2019. Data were hold back by my supervisor until disclosure of the analysis in the preregistration.

The project aims to examine whether the effect, the expressive intensity used by a speaker to state his opinion has on subjects’ attitude change, evaluations of trustworthiness of the speaker and credibility of the message, varies depending on perceived source competency. 

While 11 000 scientists warn of the consequences of the climate change, politicians all over the world still doubt its mere existence. How is it possible that some people are persuasive even when their message contradicts profound scientific findings? What makes up persuasion? 						
One of the factors that has been regarded as important concerning persuasive effects is language intensity. Language intensity can be defined as “the quality of language which indicate[s] the degree to which the speaker’s attitude toward a concept deviates from neutrality” (Bowers, 1963, p. 345). It’s not quite clear which effect language intensity has on persuasion. While Buller et al. (2000) could find that high intense language produced more compliance with sun protection recommendations than low intense language, Bowers (1963) could find quite the opposite effect. In his study, low intensity messages were even more convincing than high intensity messages. He drew the conclusion that the effect of language intensity on persuasion should be researched in combination with other factors (Bowers, 1963). This is also postulated by the Language Expectancy Theory, which claims that persuasion is a result of interaction between message strategies (e.g. language intensity) and expectations of the person being persuaded. Expectations are defined as “a function of cultural values and societal standards or ideals for competent communication” (Buller et al., 2000, p. 104). The theory predicts that a message strategy that violates expectations in a positive way will be persuasive. If, for example, a person low in competency, who would normally be expected to use intensive language, uses a very formal and moderate language style he violates expectations in a positive way (Clementson, Pascual-Ferrá & Betty, 2014). Hamilton, Hunter and Burgoon (1990) could support these theoretical assumptions with empirical evidence. They confronted university students from Hawaii with messages concerning the legalization of heroin. In this experiment, highly credible sources were more persuasive when using intense language, while low credible sources were less persuasive when using intense language. 
Unfortunately, not all evidence is pointing towards the predictions of Language Expectancy theory. Clementson et al. (2014) could report that presidential candidates, using a low-intensity language were perceived as more credible than candidates using high-intensity language. This result, however, must not necessarily be interpreted as the refutation of Language Expectancy theory. In our eyes, it throws light on the problematic operationalization of language intensity. Clementson et al. (2014) for example used a very hostile and aggressive stimulus material that also differed from the content of the stimulus material in the low-intensity language condition. It is likely that this unwanted aggressiveness in the language had a negative effect on perceived credibility, which made candidates that used low-intensity language look more credible (König and Jucks, 2019). 
Instead of varying language intensity, we want to extent language intensity theory to nonverbal and paraverbal communication, since this operationalization allows us to use content consistent stimulus material which is not confounded by other variables such as aggression. Although the markers of language intensity are directness towards the audience and emotionalism of word choice (Hamilton and Hunter, 1998) the predictions of the theory should also extend to other communication markers, which show how far a communicator’s attitude differs from neutrality.  In our experiment we will therefore vary the expressive intensity by varying vocal dynamics (volume, accentuation, intonation), gestures and facial expression over the course of our experimental conditions. Our theoretical hypothesis are formulated on the predictions of language expectancy theory.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Being introduced as competent, in comparison to being introduced as incompetent, increases the perceived trustworthiness of a person stating its opinion, the perceived credibility of his message and the probability that attitude change occurs. 

Hypothesis 2: The effect of expressive intensity on attitude change, trustworthiness and credibility ratings depends on the source’s competence. 

Hypothesis 2a: Being introduced as competent in combination with high expressive intensity results in higher trustworthiness and credibility ratings and a higher probability that attitude change occurs compared to a low expressive intensity. 

Hypothesis 2b: Being introduced as incompetent in combination with high expressive intensity results in lower trustworthiness and credibility ratings and a lower probability that attitude change occurs compared to a low expressive intensity.

question.value:
Design and Procedure 

The experiment follows a 2 (high vs. low intensity expression) x2 (high vs. low competence manipulation) within-subject experimental design. Since the experiment will be conducted in German, translated versions of all questionnaires can be retrieved from Appendix A. 
After indicating informed consent, providing demographic information and completing a volume calibration test, participants respond to items measuring their attitude, their attitude clarity and attitude correctness. Then participants are given a short information about the person in the upcoming video which manipulates their expected competence of the speaker. Afterwards they watch a video in which an actor talks about one out of four topics. Each participant watches two videos in the high expressive intensity condition and two videos in the low expressive intensity condition. For each expressive intensity condition one actor is introduced as competent regarding the topic and the other one as less competent. After watching the videos participants get asked about their attitude change regarding the topic of the video, the credibility of the message, the trustworthiness of the speaker and some additional filler items and exclusion criteria. The procedure is being repeated four times for each video.

question.value:
Data collection is planned as part of a longer experimental session in which one other experiment will also be run. The planned N of collection is 80 (selected for economic reasons). Once the criterion of 80 is achieved, data collection will continue for all already scheduled lab slots and then terminate. If the criterion is not achieved within an acceptable time frame (likely about 4 weeks depending on pressure for lab capacity), data collection may end prematurely. This sample would be sensitive to an effect size of f = .119 (f = .126 if 10% of cases are dropped) with a power of 80% in a within-subjects MANOVA assuming r = 0.5 for the within-subject measures. The sample would be sensitive to an effect size of f = .169 (f= .178 if 10% of cases are dropped) with a power of 80% in a within-subjects MANOVA assuming r = 0 for the within-subject measures.
The sample will be recruited from the psychological institute’s mailing list, which comprises a sample of predominantly students with a significant minority of other demographics. The sample is skewed towards higher education and is predominantly white (German). Participants will be paid a total of 10€ for their time (expected session length: 60min). 

Participant exclusion criteria 

Participants are excluded from analysis based on the following criteria (in order):
• Experimenter notes anomalies in behaviour as problematic for analysis (e.g. participant is clearly drunk, agitated or otherwise influenced; participant clearly ignores task instructions) at time of data collection

• Participant’s data is incomplete

• Participant indicates that he knows one or more of the actors in the videos 

• Participants indicated that his judgements about the topics after watching the respective video were based on “random pressing” 

• Participant indicates that he didn’t take the information about the speaker into account

question.value:
Competence manipulation. 

Participants read a fake profile of the actors who are being displayed in the videos. Profiles include name, age, profession, education and experience concerning the topic of the contribution. While some profiles imply high competency regarding the topic, some profiles imply low competency. The full profiles can be retrieved from Appendix B.

Video stimuli and expressive intensity manipulation. 

In the videos an actor states their opinion regarding four different topics (“Use of nuclear power as an energy source”, “Reintroduction of compulsory military service”, “Change of voting age to 16” and “Centralisation of the education system”). Each actor is assigned to one of the topics. Videos are 3:30 to 4:50 minutes long. For each video there is a high expressive intensity version and a low expressive intensity version. In the high expressive intensity videos, the actors vary the intonation, emotional facial expression and show strong gestures, while in the low expressive intensity videos the actors show a neutral tone without strong emotional facial expression, dynamic intonation or gestures. The scripts for the actors can be retrieved from Appendix C and the videos are attached as well.

Attitude change and attitude certainty

Participants get three statements to measure their attitude before and after watching the videos as an indicator for attitude change (e.g. “I completely reject nuclear power as a means of producing energy ”). After indicating their attitude towards the topic they receive seven statements to measure attitude certainty regarding the topic, four to measure attitude clarity (e.g. “How sure are you that you know what your true attitude towards nuclear power really is?”) and three to measure attitude correctness (e.g. “How sure are you that your attitude to nuclear power is the right one?”). Measures are taken from Petrocelli, Tormala and Rucker (2007). They indicate how much they disagree or agree to the statements on a scale from 1 (“not at all”) to 7 (“very much”). Attitude certainty is measured for exploratory research.

Message credibility

Participants rate the credibility of the provided information with a translated version of the Message Credibility Scale (Appelman and Sundar, 2016). Participants indicate how well three adjectives, for example „authentic” describe the content they just heard on a scale from 1 (“very poorly”) to 7 (“very well”). 

Speaker trustworthiness

A translated version of the Muenster Epistemic Trustworthiness Inventory (Hendriks, Kienhues & Bromme, 2015) is used to assess the trustworthiness of the speaker. Participants rate the trustworthiness through 15 items on a scale ranging from 1 (e.g. “competent”) to 7 (e.g. “incompetent”). The items measure expertise (six items, e.g. “qualified - unqualified”), benevolence (four items, e.g. “moral- immoral”) and integrity (four items, “sincere - insincere”).

For each measure, individual items will be aggregated to mean scores. An attitude change index will be calculated by subtracting the attitude measure mean pre-video from the attitude measure mean post-video. The speaker trustworthiness measure will be recorded in a way that positive ratings equate to higher numbers.

Both hypothesis 1 and hypothesis 2 will be assessed using a MANOVA with repeated measures. The two factors will be speaker competence (high vs. low) and expressive intensity (high vs. low). The dependent variables will be attitude change, trustworthiness of source and credibility of speaker. As MANOVA test value we will use Pillai’s Trace

q21.value:
For hypothesis 1, the critical effect in the model will be the main effect of speaker competence on the complete model. The expected pattern is high > low. The criterion for interference is p ≤ .05. 
For hypothesis 2, the critical effect in the model will be the main effect of the interaction term of speaker competence and expressive intensity on the complete model. The expected pattern is that high vs. low expressive intensity is more advantageous for high competence speakers than for low competence speakers. The criterion for inference is p ≤ .05 for the effect and any pattern consistent with that described (post-hoc comparisons of model estimates will be calculated for descriptive purposes). Although a stricter test of the hypothesis might be conceived (e.g. a negative effect of high expressive intensity for low competence speakers), the novel paradigm implies the necessity for more latitude in predictions.

q23.value: Through the way the experiment is programmed missing data shouldn't occur. If, nevertheless, missing data occurs it's defined as an exclusion criterion.

q24.value: All other analyses (including those of the main effect of expressive intensity as well as analyses probing moderation by attitude certainty, effects on source or message credibility and mediation of any effects on attitude change by the prior) will be considered exploratory.

Data collection started at 12th of December and finished at the 18th of December 2019. Data were hold back by my supervisor until disclosure of the analysis in the preregistration.

attributes.title: Pain in presence: How empathy for pain is modulated by the presence of the other person

q1.value: Pain in presence: How empathy for pain is modulated by the presence of the other person

q3.value:
In a paradigm including direct social interaction and social interaction via real-time video recording, we want to investigate the follwoing research questions: What are the effects of another person’s direct social presence on behavioral and physiological correlates of empathizing with that persons’ pain?

1.	What effect has social presence on empathizing?
2.	What effect has social presence on peripheral physiological activity (coupling)?

q4.value:
1.	Behaviorally, we expect stronger empathizing (higher unpleasantness scores and better matching between target’s and observer’s pain intensity rating) with the other person’s pain in the Presence condition, compared to the Online condition.
2.	For the cardiovascular (ECG, heart period)- and electrodermal activity (EDA)-responses to the other being stimulated, two different hypotheses are plausible: A) Social presence could enhance overall physiological arousal, or B) Social presence could specifically enhance salience of social cues that trigger empathy, namely cues that the other is in pain. From these assumptions we draw different hypotheses: 
A.	We expect stronger reactions to the other being stimulated in the Presence than in the Online condition. For the ECG, we expect a stronger heart rate deceleration and then acceleration to the pain and the no-pain cues in the Presence than in the Online condition. For the EDA responses, we expect higher peak amplitudes to the pain and the no-pain cues in the Presence than in the Online condition.
B.	We expect stronger reactions in the Presence than in the Online condition specifically to the pain cues. For the ECG, we expect a stronger heart rate deceleration and then acceleration specifically to the pain cues in the Presence than in the Online condition. For the EDA responses, we expect higher peak amplitudes specifically to the pain cues in the Presence than in the Online condition.
3.	We expect stronger coupling of cardiovascular (heart period) and electrodermal activity between target and observer in the Presence condition, compared to the Online condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The main part of the study is a pain observation paradigm in which we will compare an observer’s response to a target’s pain while the target is present (condition: Presence) to a condition where the target is observed in an online video (similar to a live video chat, e.g. via Skype) (condition: Online). First, we will measure the observer’s behavioral and physiological response when being exposed to pain her- or himself. Second, we will perform the actual pain observation paradigm. ECG and EDA will be recorded from target and observer in all conditions. 

Pain stimulation protocol: 
The protocol for the delivery of the pain stimuli follows closely the well-established empathy for pain paradigm as described in Rütgen et al., (2015). Before the actual procedure, the intensity of the stimulation will be calibrated to the subjective pain experience of the participant. To this end, stimulations with different intensities will be presented and the participant will rate each on a Likert scale from 1 (“clearly perceivable but not painful”) to 7 (“unbearably painful”). In the following experiment, a range of stimulation intensities rated between 1 and 2 ("unpleasant") will be used for the non-painful trials and a range of stimulation intensities rated between 5 ("very painful") and 6 ("extremely painful") will be used for the painful trials. Each trial will consist of an auditory cue indicating the intensity of the following stimulation (tone 1 -> no pain, tone 2 -> pain). After a waiting phase of 1000 ms, the electrical stimulation will be delivered for 500 ms (consisting of 20 electrical  pulses of 2 ms duration with a 24.2 ms break after each pulse). Afterwards, there will be a variable interstimulus interval of 7500-9000 ms, followed in a third of the trials by the rating of the stimulus (12 s, onset indicated by a short beep). In conditions where the participants him- or herself receives the electric stimulation, the rating consists of one question addressing the perceived pain intensity (on a visual analogue scale from "not painful at all" to "extremely painful"). In conditions where the participant observes the other receiving the electric stimulation, the question on pain intensity refers to the inferred pain intensity felt by the other, and another question is added that refers to one’s own unpleasantness while watching the stimulation (on a Likert scale from "not unpleasant at all" to "extremely unpleasant"). Each condition will consist of 80 trials (40 painful and 40 non-painful trials). The order of the stimuli will be randomized, but with no more than 4 stimulations of the same intensity in a row, and with the same order for all participants. One pain stimulation condition will take approximately 20  minutes. Stimulation will be delivered with a Digitimer DS5 Isolated Bipolar Constant Current Stimulator (Digitimer Clinical and Biomedical Research Instruments) via a   bar electrode attached to the back of the right hand. This hand will always be placed flat on the table in front of the participant. A tablet will be placed at the front left of the participant on the table to display the evaluation questions and record participants button presses with the left hand.


Pain observation paradigm (“Observers” and “Targets”): 
In this part of the experiment, the “observers” will observe one of the above-mentioned targets in the two different conditions (“Presence” and “Online”). The observer will see the same target for each condition. The matching of targets and observers will be carried out in a way that each target is observed by five observers (and hence has to come to the laboratory 5 times in total). The order of the two conditions will be permutated between observers to control for possible order effects. During the complete experiment, both target and observer will be videotaped. These videos will be presented to an independent group of participants to assess similarities and differences of the target’s behavior between the conditions and to record possible facial expressions of the observer in response to the painful stimulation of the target. 
Prior to watching the target in the different conditions, the same procedure as for the targets to adjust the intensity of the electric shocks will be conducted for the observers. Then observers will undergo the pain stimulation procedure themselves. This is done to assess the behavioral and physiological responses during own pain experience to be able to compare this to the activity during the observation of pain in others and to make it easier for the observer to imagine what the stimulation feels like for the target. To save time, the pain stimulation of the observer will be shorter than the other conditions and consist of only 12 trials. 

Presence condition: 
In the presence condition, observers will sit in front of the target at a table. The target will then undergo the pain stimulation protocol. In a third of the trials, observer and target will answer the rating questions. Observers are instructed to look at the target’s right hand during the whole task apart from when they answer the rating questions. The background of the target will be set up in the same way as in the Online condition (a blue cloth).

Online condition: 
In the Online condition, the observer will sit in front of a screen and a camera. The target will sit in a separate room, also in front of a camera and a screen. The camera recording the target will be connected to the screen in front of the observer and vice versa, such that target and observer can see each other in real time. The observer will watch the target undergoing the pain stimulation again, also instructed to look at the right hand of the target during the whole video apart from when answering the rating questions. The observer will also be videotaped during this condition to assess possible reactions to the target’s pain shown in the facial expressions.

q9.value: The order of the two conditions will be randomized between subjects in a way that each target is observed first in the Online condition and then in the Presence condition by approximately half of the observers and the other way around by the other half.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Registration will be completed prior to data creation.

question.value:
Subjects will be two targets and ten observers from a population of adults aged 18 to 35. They need to be right-handed, mentally, neurologically and cardiovascularly healthy (by own account) and have no chronic pain disorder, or pain condition within the last week (by own account). Moreover there should have been no medication intake in the last 48 h (apart from contraceptives, by own account).

Targets: 
We will ask only female psychology students of the higher semester (master) to serve as targets. We use E-mails as well as word of mouth to distribute invitations to the appropriate departments at the University of Luebeck. Participants will be reimbursed for their time at a rate of 10€ per hour. The targets need to have some commitment in terms of time and willingness to undergo repeated pain stimulation. Additionally, experience with psychological experiments is necessary or at least helpful to ensure high reliability of the behavior in the pain stimulation protocol. Therefore, we will recruit psychology students who are familiar with psychological experiments and who are interested in psychological research. As the majority of psychology students are female and to keep the factor of target’s gender constant, we will only include female targets for this study. 

Observers: 
There will be approximately 50% female and 50% male observers. Observers should be recruited mainly from the lower semesters, so that they do not know the targets. Participants will be recruited via E-Mail advertisement and postings on the University of Luebeck campus. Participants will be reimbursed for their time at a rate of 10€ per hour or course credit.

q13.value: There will be ten observers and two persons who will each serve as targets for five observers.

q14.value: As this is a pilot-study to test the paradigm, ten participants were considered sufficient to test for the within-subjects main effects.

q15.value: Once all the targets and observers have been collected recruitment will stop.

question.value: We will be manipulating the factor of social presence. There will be the two conditions Presence and Online, which every observer will go through (within-subject manipulation).

Behavioral:
To assess the empathic behavior of the observer we will collect pain intensity and unpleasantness ratings from the observer and pain intensity ratings from the target. 

Physiological data:
We will assess heart period and EDA evoked by the pain stimuli, by watching the other in pain and the sound predicting the pain stimuli.
We do not intend to combine measures into an index.

Behavioral:
To assess the impact of the Presence vs. Online condition on behavioral empathy, the correlation between the target’s and the observer’s pain intensity ratings will be compared between conditions. The unpleasantness ratings of the observer will be compared between conditions using a repeated measures ANOVA.

Physiological data:
Regarding the observer’s ECG, the Inter-Beat-Interval (IBI) in seconds 2-5 (deceleration expected) after the pain cue sound will be compared between the Presence and the Online condition and between pain and no-pain trials using a repeated measures ANOVA. 
Regarding the observer’s EDA, the maximal peak amplitude between the sound cue and the onset of the next trial will be compared between the Presence and Online condition and between the pain and no-pain trials using a repeated measures ANOVA. 

The coupling between the heart period and electrodermal activity of the target and the observer will be assessed with correlations between the two time-series and compared between the conditions. We will use lagged cross-correlation that allows analysis adjusted for the time delay between the peripheral activity of target and observer. First, we will assess at which time lag the correlation is maximal in each condition. Then, we will compare the time lags statistically to test the hypothesis that coupling appears with a longer time delay in the Online condition than in the Presence condition. Additionally, to test the hypothesis that the coupling is stronger in the Presence than in the Online condition, we will compare the maximum correlation between the two time-series in the two conditions using Fisher’s z-test.

q20.value:
Electrodermal activity data will be normalized using log-transformation. The maximum peak amplitude in the time window from 1-4 s after cue sound onset will be baseline-corrected to activity in the 2 s before cue sound onset. 
The Inter-Beat-Interval (ECG) will be baseline corrected to 1 second before cue sound onset.

q21.value: We will regard p-values less than .050 as criteria for statistically significant results. We will regard p-values between .050 and .100 (inclusive) as being marginally significant. As our hypotheses are unidirectional our tests will be one-tailed.

q22.value: Data will be excluded if participants fail to comprehend the task or comply with experimenter instructions. We exclude participants who have an insufficient amount of physiological data (less than 1/3 of the trials per condition are useable).

q23.value: For the correlation analyses missing data will be excluded pairwise. The correlation will be calculated using the remaining data points.

q24.value: We will test for different time lags for the cross correlation in the different conditions.

q25.value: This study is intended to be a pilot study to test the paradigm and main effects before testing the hypotheses in a larger sample. Therefore, further exploratory analyses will be conducted.

registration_responses.q1: Pain in presence: How empathy for pain is modulated by the presence of the other person
registration_responses.q3:
In a paradigm including direct social interaction and social interaction via real-time video recording, we want to investigate the follwoing research questions: What are the effects of another person’s direct social presence on behavioral and physiological correlates of empathizing with that persons’ pain?

1.	What effect has social presence on empathizing?
2.	What effect has social presence on peripheral physiological activity (coupling)?
registration_responses.q4:
1.	Behaviorally, we expect stronger empathizing (higher unpleasantness scores and better matching between target’s and observer’s pain intensity rating) with the other person’s pain in the Presence condition, compared to the Online condition.
2.	For the cardiovascular (ECG, heart period)- and electrodermal activity (EDA)-responses to the other being stimulated, two different hypotheses are plausible: A) Social presence could enhance overall physiological arousal, or B) Social presence could specifically enhance salience of social cues that trigger empathy, namely cues that the other is in pain. From these assumptions we draw different hypotheses: 
A.	We expect stronger reactions to the other being stimulated in the Presence than in the Online condition. For the ECG, we expect a stronger heart rate deceleration and then acceleration to the pain and the no-pain cues in the Presence than in the Online condition. For the EDA responses, we expect higher peak amplitudes to the pain and the no-pain cues in the Presence than in the Online condition.
B.	We expect stronger reactions in the Presence than in the Online condition specifically to the pain cues. For the ECG, we expect a stronger heart rate deceleration and then acceleration specifically to the pain cues in the Presence than in the Online condition. For the EDA responses, we expect higher peak amplitudes specifically to the pain cues in the Presence than in the Online condition.
3.	We expect stronger coupling of cardiovascular (heart period) and electrodermal activity between target and observer in the Presence condition, compared to the Online condition.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The main part of the study is a pain observation paradigm in which we will compare an observer’s response to a target’s pain while the target is present (condition: Presence) to a condition where the target is observed in an online video (similar to a live video chat, e.g. via Skype) (condition: Online). First, we will measure the observer’s behavioral and physiological response when being exposed to pain her- or himself. Second, we will perform the actual pain observation paradigm. ECG and EDA will be recorded from target and observer in all conditions. 

Pain stimulation protocol: 
The protocol for the delivery of the pain stimuli follows closely the well-established empathy for pain paradigm as described in Rütgen et al., (2015). Before the actual procedure, the intensity of the stimulation will be calibrated to the subjective pain experience of the participant. To this end, stimulations with different intensities will be presented and the participant will rate each on a Likert scale from 1 (“clearly perceivable but not painful”) to 7 (“unbearably painful”). In the following experiment, a range of stimulation intensities rated between 1 and 2 ("unpleasant") will be used for the non-painful trials and a range of stimulation intensities rated between 5 ("very painful") and 6 ("extremely painful") will be used for the painful trials. Each trial will consist of an auditory cue indicating the intensity of the following stimulation (tone 1 -> no pain, tone 2 -> pain). After a waiting phase of 1000 ms, the electrical stimulation will be delivered for 500 ms (consisting of 20 electrical  pulses of 2 ms duration with a 24.2 ms break after each pulse). Afterwards, there will be a variable interstimulus interval of 7500-9000 ms, followed in a third of the trials by the rating of the stimulus (12 s, onset indicated by a short beep). In conditions where the participants him- or herself receives the electric stimulation, the rating consists of one question addressing the perceived pain intensity (on a visual analogue scale from "not painful at all" to "extremely painful"). In conditions where the participant observes the other receiving the electric stimulation, the question on pain intensity refers to the inferred pain intensity felt by the other, and another question is added that refers to one’s own unpleasantness while watching the stimulation (on a Likert scale from "not unpleasant at all" to "extremely unpleasant"). Each condition will consist of 80 trials (40 painful and 40 non-painful trials). The order of the stimuli will be randomized, but with no more than 4 stimulations of the same intensity in a row, and with the same order for all participants. One pain stimulation condition will take approximately 20  minutes. Stimulation will be delivered with a Digitimer DS5 Isolated Bipolar Constant Current Stimulator (Digitimer Clinical and Biomedical Research Instruments) via a   bar electrode attached to the back of the right hand. This hand will always be placed flat on the table in front of the participant. A tablet will be placed at the front left of the participant on the table to display the evaluation questions and record participants button presses with the left hand.


Pain observation paradigm (“Observers” and “Targets”): 
In this part of the experiment, the “observers” will observe one of the above-mentioned targets in the two different conditions (“Presence” and “Online”). The observer will see the same target for each condition. The matching of targets and observers will be carried out in a way that each target is observed by five observers (and hence has to come to the laboratory 5 times in total). The order of the two conditions will be permutated between observers to control for possible order effects. During the complete experiment, both target and observer will be videotaped. These videos will be presented to an independent group of participants to assess similarities and differences of the target’s behavior between the conditions and to record possible facial expressions of the observer in response to the painful stimulation of the target. 
Prior to watching the target in the different conditions, the same procedure as for the targets to adjust the intensity of the electric shocks will be conducted for the observers. Then observers will undergo the pain stimulation procedure themselves. This is done to assess the behavioral and physiological responses during own pain experience to be able to compare this to the activity during the observation of pain in others and to make it easier for the observer to imagine what the stimulation feels like for the target. To save time, the pain stimulation of the observer will be shorter than the other conditions and consist of only 12 trials. 

Presence condition: 
In the presence condition, observers will sit in front of the target at a table. The target will then undergo the pain stimulation protocol. In a third of the trials, observer and target will answer the rating questions. Observers are instructed to look at the target’s right hand during the whole task apart from when they answer the rating questions. The background of the target will be set up in the same way as in the Online condition (a blue cloth).

Online condition: 
In the Online condition, the observer will sit in front of a screen and a camera. The target will sit in a separate room, also in front of a camera and a screen. The camera recording the target will be connected to the screen in front of the observer and vice versa, such that target and observer can see each other in real time. The observer will watch the target undergoing the pain stimulation again, also instructed to look at the right hand of the target during the whole video apart from when answering the rating questions. The observer will also be videotaped during this condition to assess possible reactions to the target’s pain shown in the facial expressions.

q2.value: Jingshi Liu, S. Wiley Wakeman, Michael I Norton

q3.value: In this study, we test how perceived income inequality affects people's perceptions of a genuine vs. a counterfeit phone.

q4.value: Under high (vs. low) income inequality, consumers are more likely to perceive counterfeit (vs. genuine) products to have greater egalitarian value. The egalitarian value in turn positively affects consumers' attitudes toward counterfeits. The effect of egalitarian value on counterfeit attitudes should be independent of the hedonic, utilitarian, status signaling, and economic values of a counterfeit.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2 between-subject (video: income inequality, neutral) X 2 within-subject (phone: counterfeit, genuine) mixed design.

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to one of the 2 (video: income inequality, neutral). In the income inequality condition, they watch a video about wealth inequality in the US. In the neutral video, they watch a video about brain science.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will post the study on MTurk. Participants will receive monetary rewards for their participation. MTurk workers who are located in the U.S., with a 95% HIT acceptance rate are eligible to participate. Before they can start the study, they must pass two screening questions to make sure they are not robots. One question requires basic human logic and common sense (e.g., up is to down as left is to ___?) and the other question is a Qualtrics Catcha. We will include an attention check and a comprehension check for the video prime in the study. Data from participants who fail either or both checks will be excluded from analyses.

q14.value: Based on the results from our previous studies, a cell size of 150 is pre-determined.

q15.value: We will collect data until the sample size is met.

question.value: Video prime: participants watch a video either about income inequality in the US, or a neutral video about brain science.

Dependent variables: Participants report the following perceived values of both a genuine iPhone, and a counterfeit GooPhone: hednic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value. Additional dependent variables: They reported the extent to which they would like to purchase the phone, and the dollar amount they are willing to pay for the phone. Potential covariates and moderators: They reported the extent to which they think counterfeit products are acceptable, prevalent, and easy to detect in their society. They reported individual difference in Social Dominance Orientation and socioeconomic status, as well as demographic variables.

All the scale measures with more than one item will be combined into an index by averaging the scores of all items in the scale. Before creating the index, we will first reversed code the items that are phrased reservedly. We will also test the reliability of the scale before creating the index. A chrombach's alpha = .7 is considered acceptable.

1) Separate ANOVAs on each of the dependent measures will be conducted, using the video prime as a factor. We compute the difference score for each dependent variable between the iPhone and the GooPhone. 2) We will test parallel mediating effect of the different relative perceived values (hedonic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value) on the effect of video prime on purchase intention toward counterfeits. 3) We will test the serial mediating effect of perceived acceptance and prevalence of counterfeits on consumers' purchase intentions. 4) We will test the potential moderating effect of Social dominance orientation.

q20.value: Skewed dependent variables will be log transformed.

q21.value: p= .1 is marginally significant. p = .05 is significant. We will test simple effects of any interactions that are marginally significant.

q22.value: Data from participants who fail the attention check and the comprehension check will be excluded from analyses.

q23.value: Participants with incomplete data will be excluded from analyses.

q24.value: We will test the moderating effect of perceived social acceptance and social prevalence of counterfeits, if they are not affected by the income inequality manipulation. We will test the moderating effect of social dominance orientation. We will test the moderating effect of socioeconomic status.

attributes.title: Harm Reduction Interventions for Infective Endocarditis

summary.value: Harm reduction is the implementation of practical strategies to reduce the negative consequences of drug use. In view of the increasing recognition of Addiction Medicine, principles of harm reduction have been applied to many areas of medicine. However, harm reduction strategies have been inconsistently instituted in the infective endocarditis (IE) population. IE is significantly more prevalent among people who inject drugs (PWID), and treatment outcomes are far worse in PWID who have IE compared outcomes of IE not associated with drug use. In some patients, PWID are withheld life-saving surgery due to concerns about continued substance use and the susceptibility of replacement valves to reinfection. For this reason, research has suggested that focused harm reduction strategies for PWID who develop IE could be a cost-effective and life-saving intervention. However, this remains an area that has received fairly limited attention. Here, we conduct a systematic review to identify which harm reduction interventions have been previously implemented in PWID who develop IE.

attributes.title: Replikationsstudie "Blinks of the eye predict blinks of the mind" nach Colzato et al. (2008)
attributes.description: Replikationsstudie nach Colzato et al. (2008) anlässlich des Moduls M4 an der FernUni Schweiz HS2019

summary.value: This Projects implements replicated Experiment titled Blinks of the eye predict blinks of the mind by Colzato,  Slagter, Spapé and Hommel (2008), Neuropsychologia (Doi: 10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2008.07.006) as an online Experiment. The project is part of graded student work to fulfill the requirements of a course on information & communication technology in research.
